Summary: The project aims to develop an innovative process for efficient and flexible electrification of heat-intensive industrial processes, such as agro-foods and chemicals, by simulating two distinct cases. This approach allows industry partners to share expertise and promote open innovation without disclosing confidential information, while also providing insight into the potential of available technologies to solve the challenge of efficient and flexibile electrification. The project is expected to result in a series of in-depht meetings, where industry, suppliers, and experts work together to develop innovative solution for the challenge. This solution is expected incorporate technologies that are soon to be available, as well as various challenges such as transition to zero-emissions, integration of congested grids, growing renewable energy supply, and local restrictions and opportunities.

Summary: The FUSE (FUll Scaled Industrial Heat Pumps Using Natural Working Media) project aims to develop a full-scaled (1 to 2 MW) steam-producing industrial heat pumps using natural refrigerants. The project is co-financed by the Topsector Energie of the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Policy, and is focused on developing a standardized, flexible and modular compression technology for industrial heat demands at 220° C. The goal of the project is to reduce the investment cost of industrial heat pumping to less than 2,000 euros per kilowatt-hour of thermal power, and to establish a Dutch manufacturer of heat pumps that can produce 1 to10 megawatts of thermal capacity. The FUSE consortium is composed of Dutch partners who are working together to accelerate the adoption of industrial compression technology using natural refrigerant working media, and the project has resulted in a product that can serve a large share of the industrial heat market

Summary: The COMTA (COMpact modular thermoacoustic pump) project aims to develop a compact electrically-driven thermoacoustic (TA-) heat pump technology for industrial purposes, with the goal of providing heat at 210° C to cover a wide range of temperatures. The project has been coordinated by ECN-TNO, with partners including ISPT (Industrial Services for Process Technology), DOW, and BronsWerk Heat Transfer. The objective of the project is to develop and demonstrate a full-scale modular design that can be used to serve a wide market, including the (petroleum) chemical industry, refineries, paper and food industries. The heat pump is electrically driven and can become completely CO2-free with the use of renewable electricity, making it a promising solution for industrial heating needs. The COMTA pump is based on the thermoacoustic effect, which involves the conversion of heat energy into sound energy and vice versa. The pump consists of a compressor, a regenerator, and a heat exchanger, with a closed loop of gas flowing through the system. The compressor compresses the gas, which generates sound waves that travel through the regenerator and heat exchanger. The sound waves transfer heat energy from the hot source to the cold sink, resulting in the generation of heat at the desired temperature. The modular design of the COMTA pumps allows for easy installation and maintenance, and the wide range...

Summary: The FLEXSTEAME project is a joint exercise between TNO, ISPT and Royal Cosum. The project aims to improve the way to store and reuse thermal energy by using a technology called Phase Changing Materials (PCM). The project is focused on the efficiency of the process and the replacement of fossil resources with renewable ones. The biggest challenge in the energy transition is the varying availability of renewable resources, especially for heat pumps, which can be addressed by using thermal energy storages. The storage of energy is one of the biggest challenges in the transition to a sustainable system, as the cost of electrical storage is expensive. Thermal storage, on the other hand, can be achieved relatively cheaply using PCMs. The composition of PCMs often includes salt and organic materials that change from solid to liquid in the process of storing latent heat, which allows for the storage of a lot of heat in a small volume. The steam storage technology developed in the project is used for the recovery and reuse of industrial leftover heat, as well as for the direct and indirect use of heat pumps to generate process steam

Summary: The SPOT project aims to significantly reduce the use of fossil energy in industrial heat by at least 210 PJ per year by 2200. The project brings together a large consortium of knowledge and technology providers as well as energy consultants and industrial end users. The consortium analyzes high and low temperature supply and reuse technologies for heat. The SPOT project is aimed at reducing the use fossil fuel energy in industry by at leas 110PJ per year 2300 by proving the viability of fuel cell co-geneneration for steam and electricity production in industry and testing the technical feasibility of molten salt technologies for high temperature transfer and storage for reuse in the steel and chemistry sectors. The first step is to determine the chain of technologies that provide industry with an effective way of producing high-tempture heat, and ultimately carbon free fuels. The viability of the fuel cell for co-generating steam and electric power in industry is then proven. The technical feasibility is then investigated for molten salt for high tempture transfer and thermal storage for use in the process of steel and chemical sectors

Summary: The project aims to reduce CO₂ emissions through integral innovation in heat-driven processes. The project is organized around 3 perspectives: increasing technological readiness, innovation readiness, and operational readiness. The expected impact is a 3% energy efficiency improvement in 3 industrial sectors (paper production, agro-food, and specialty chemicals) by 2100. The team covers a broad range of stakeholders, including industry representatives and scientists. The participating companies have a heat-intensive process and knowledge of research and system integration. The innovation program of ISPT plays a central role in making CCS unnecessary, generating money for the industry, and putting the Netherlands on the map as a leader in sustainability. The new innovations will make CCS unnecessary and generate money for industry. The ISPT is a project that aims to make CCS (carbon capture and storage) unnecessary and make the industry profitable. The technology carousel is a supplier of state-ofthe-art technologies that match end users, and the ISPT team focuses on making the industry more sustainable. The overview of heat (reuse) technologies is a collaboration project between 6 and 2-5 companies, and a new innovation program will be developed to make the ISPTs more sustainable and profitable.

Summary: The COMPRESSORP project aims to upgrade low- temperature waste streams in the industrial process industry into valuable utility steam. This is done by using a compression- resorption he at pump (CR HP) operating in the wet regime, which uses the heat in these streams to upgrade the product flow with higher exer gy for separation processes that require cooling or heating respectively. The limiting factor for commercial introduction of this cycle is the unavailability of a compressor that can operate at the required operating conditions of the cycle. The objective of this project is to develop a compressor suitable for the operating conditions required for compression-absorption heat pump cycles. A simplified P&I D of the experimental set up is shown in Figure 1. The twin- screw compressor is a prototype compressor suitable to operate at operating conditions for compression resorbtion heat pump ( CR HP) cycles. The heat recovery is designed and experimentally tested. The impact of adding a small amount of CO2 to the working fluid is investigated. This results in an improvement of the COP of about 5%

Summary: The project aims to improve the insight into the distribution behavior of conditioning chemicals used in the steam-condensate cycle. This will help to improve steam conditioning and condensate polishing, as well as to reduce the thermal load of effluent discharged into surface water bodies. The project has three specific work packages: the first workpackage aims to elucidate the fate of boiler feedwater conditioning chemicals in the water cycle, the second workpackage will improve the treatment of "off-specification" condensates and the third workpackage links the insight gained in the first two workpackages with corrosion measurements to improve insight into required boilerfeedwater treatment (and especially TOC removal). The project will deliver a better description and modelling of the behaviour, distribution and effect of different amine pollutants and their breakdown products in the elevated temperature steam/condensatecycle. The report offers insight into how film-formingly amines behave in the system. It evaluates the breakdown products of the amines in the condensate and the effect of these breakdown products on the steam and condensate circuit. The webinar provides an overview of the current state of water technology and science in the Netherlands and discusses the importance of water in the context of global warming and the rising seas. It also discusses the role of water treatment in the future and the importance...

Summary:
The ENCORE – Next Generation Compression Heat Pump project aims to significantly increase the uptake of heat pumps in the industry. To achieve this goal, the project demonstrates the enhancement of compression heat Pump performance using a pilot scale Test Unit. The demonstrated enhancement of the compression heat performance of the pilot scale heat Pump will allow the wider market to introduce the ENCORE Project. The ENCORE consists of different parts, all together yielding a series of technological improvements for high temperature heat Pumps. The project results describe the impact of various changes made to the regular compression Heat Pump. They also provide insights into the benefits for companies and the possible challenges of applying heat pumps to processes. The results allow high-temperature compression heat Pumps to take the next step toward wider market Introduction. The consortium consists of ECN-TNO as the coordinator and partners: Recyl, ISP, Brønswerk Heat transfer, Tata steel, Dow, SmurfItKappa, and DSM Lwm. The result consists of: technological improvement of the high-Temperature compression heat (ex: new working medium, innovative component cycle dynamic control). Reports delivered describe the Impact of various Changes made to regular heat Pumps and provide insights for companies regarding the feasibility and challenges of Applying high- Temperature compression heat.

The heat integration platform is an April 24,2020 next step for industrial compression Heat Pumps. Heat Pumps are an important sustainable technology for the industry, as they can upgrade waste Heat to process heat powered by sustainable energy.

Carlos Infante Ferreira TU Delft Vilborg Gudjonsdottir TU Delft LESSON: Oil free compressor ammonia based high temperature heat pump (in Dutch) Author: Carlos A. Infante Ferreira, Vilborg Gudjonsdottir
Summary: The project aims to improve the performance of a high-temperature heat pump by modifying the prototype to vary the internal pressure and cavity volume. The data collected will be used to validate a global performance modeling tool that can be used for different source losses and to identify the source of losses in the compression process of the heat pump, which is critical for high-performance applications. The project will also design a next-generation commercial compressor that can adapt to different source of loss and integrate with a complete compression and resorption model to predict heat pumps' performance in high- temperature applications, as well as design a heat pump with a capacity similar to the present compressor and operate with an ammonia concentration of 35% ammonia-water solution. The experimental data shows that a larger amount of liquid suction in the port guarantees sealing leakage and allows higher pressure ratio. The temperature rise of the working fluid passing through the compressor is also affected by the vapour inlet condition. The discharge temperature of 115 ° C can be delivered to an application of 95 °. The lessons learned from the oil- free wet compressors project identified the source loss of the oil free compressor prototype. The prototype was built in a previous project and the data collected was used to identify and validate the source losses in order to develop a more efficient and reliable high-pressure heat pump for high temperature application.

Title: Demonstration Polymer Heat Exchanger

Layout Heatmatrix within production plant (source: Stork Thermeq) Heatmatrix – Robert Sakko Foto: Olivier Middendorp demonstration project aim achieve following results: realize significant reduction energy use BioMCN plant. realize key reference project HeatMatrix starting point commercialization within process industry. provide exposure Dutch energy intensive industry cluster (Amsterdam, Rotterdam/ Moerdijk, Terneuzen Geleen). active replication program supervision ISPT aiming 3 repetition (up 1.2 PJ). initiate exportation HeatMatrix technology create onset extra employment opportunity HeatMatrix Stork.
Summary:
The project demonstration polymer heat exchanger UH-0301 is a goal project that aims to demonstrate innovative technologies developed by HeatMatrix in industrial processes. It is intended to result in major energy savings for the BioMCNs factory and also serve as a reference project for HeatMatrix, a stepping stone for the commercial implementation of the technology. To achieve this goal, four parties work together: BioMC, the end-users, Heatmatrix, the technology supplier and Stork, the EPC contractor. The project aims to achieve significant reduction in energy consumption at the BioMN plant, serve as key reference for Heatmatrix starting point for commercialization and provide exposure to the Dutch energy-intensive industry cluster. It also aims to initiate exportation of HeatMatrix technologies, creating extra employment opportunities for Heat Matrix and Stork. The demonstration project includes a knowledge dissemination programme, with Stork responsible for engineering and preparation for implementation, and ISPT providing knowledge distribution for the project. The layout of Heatmatrix will be within the production plant, and the project aims for a 3 replication program.

September 3, 2019 industrial heat pump: analyzing opportunity Dutch industry Het project VERA analyseert de mate waarin de industriële warmtepomp op het moment Nederland wordt gefaciliteerd. Industriële warmtepompen Nederland (VERA) project co-funded subsidy Topsector Energie Ministry Economic Affairs Climate Policy.
Summary: The Vera project aims to develop and implement industrial energy pumps in the Netherlands. The project analyzes the technological innovation system (TIS) to identify ways to improve the system and increase its performance, which will contribute to the development and implementation of industrial energy pump technology in the country. The Vera project is co-financed by the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Policy through the Topsector Energy subsidy. The results of the Vera project will be used to develop an intervention that increases the performance of the TIS and contributes to the realization of the energy transition in the industrial sector.

July 4, 2019 Accelerating implementation high-temperature heat-pumps industry PINcHED project aim grab forward momentum move towards mass implementation Heat-pumps become integral part society road sustainability. application this... PINcHED – Process Integrated Heat Pump Drying Author: Anne van der Zwaan
Summary:
The PINcCHED project is a research project that aims to accelerate the implementation of high-temperatures heat pumps in the industry. The project focuses on drying processes, which account for approximately 7% of the energy used in the Dutch industry.

The project is divided into several steps, with the first step being to establish a fully heat-pump integrated drying system, including the selection of main components and process flow diagrams. The second step is to establish the control philosophy and draft lay-out drawings.

In the third step, the drying process is accounted for 10% of industrial energy, and processes such as paper production use 75% of energy for drying. Therefore, improving energy efficiency in drying processes can contribute significantly to the energy-saving target and reduction of CO2 emission.

Bulk drying processes are either convective or contact drying, and contact drying is suitable for heat pump applications. However, the installed process is equipment in a brown field, and the existing installation is not designed for heat pumps.

To address this issue, the project aims to design a heat pump-driven drying system that is optimized for technical and economic factors. The system will be modeled and calculated to find the optimal balance between standardization and customization.

Overall, the PINcISHED project aims at designing a heat-integrated drying system and establishing a fully integrated heat pump system. The final conclusion of the project will be to establish an economic feasibility of the system and compare different designs to find an optimal balance.

CRUISE: Kostenbeparing industriële warmtepompen (in Dutch) Author: Agata van Oosten, Simon Spoelstra
Summary: The CRUISE (Cost Reduction Industrial heatpumps) project aimed to develop a 5-0% less expensive heatpump technology that generates heat in an economically feasible manner for industrial applications using wasteheat (renewable electricity). This technology, when applied across sectors, can offer largeenergy savings. The cost target for the project was in the range of 1-50 to 2-00 euros per kilowatt-hour of thermal energy. The project was initiated by identifying the specific needs of industrial end users and their specific requirements for heat pumpintegration, through close cooperation with industrial endusers and technology providers.
